Post_Title: God's word is absolute, yet there are 45,000 Christian denominations in the world with 45,000 different interpretations of the bible
post_text:
The interpretations of the same texts are done in different ways by different groups. There is no clear consensus on what needs to be taken literally and what as an allegory. Christians in the Middle Ages fought, killed and tortured each other due to their differences in biblical interpretations and the overall god's message.

Ive asked Christians this before and most of the answers were something along the lines:

>They all preach the same message, and theres no one religion better than the other

Yet, Mormons were trying to convert me, saying that Catholics have lost the true faith, the Evangelicals tried to convert me, the Jehova's witnesses tried to convert me. There are about 20 different churches in my town in NY. Few of them dont even have a denomination, they simply call themselves the True Christians, as in, they claim that they understand the bible as it was meant to be understood, True Christians also told me that Mormon missionaries who tried to convert me, don't understand god's message, and thats why they invented their own books on top of the Bible, in order to promote their own separate views.

If they all preach the same message, why are there denominations that have direct animosity towards the others, and direct contradictions in the text interpretations?

If (Christian) god wanted his message to be known by all humans, then why is everyone so confused about it? Is (Christian) god not wise enough and doesn't know how to make everyone understand the absolute meaning? Or is everyone just led astray and only one select denomination is the true follower of god? How do you know that your denomination is the True Christian?

Whenever a Christian is faced with this question, they seem to choose a denomination that is either closer to their cultural upbringing, their immediate geographical location and/or their dissatisfaction with the previous religion/denomination. It seems like the choice is mainly influenced by personal bias at the time.

​

My main problem with Omnipotence can be summed up with the paradox of the stone. Its a pretty classic argument so you have likely heard it before, but it goes as follows.

1) God Exists

2) God is Omnipotent

3) Since God is Omnipotent he can do anything

4) Since God is omnipotent, God can create a stone too heavy that God can not lift it.

5) Since God can not lift this stone he is not Omnipotent. This giving us a contradiction.

There are plenty of variations of this theorem, but the point is clear. If God is Omnipotent we must conclude god is not Omnipotent. Thus making the very concept of Omnipotence self-contradictory.
